body:
Sometimes it is useful to be able to not only show information in the top border (a.k.a. title), but also in the bottom one (a.k.a. footer).

This PR adds the ability to set footer similar to title. Added functionality:
- New allowed `footer` and `footer_pos` fields for floating window options, which behave similar to `title` and `title_pos` respectively.
- New `FloatFooter` highlight group to go along with `FloatTitle`.

What I actually did:
- Refactored code using `title` and/or `title_pos` into reusable chunks (where it seemed reasonable).
- Updated those code chunks to behave accordingly for footer. Tried to cover any place where `title` is used for floating window, but could have missed some.
- Added tests similar to testing of `title` and `title_pos`.
- Added new `FloatBorder` highlight group updating any its occurrence to also have `FloatFooter`.

Notes/questions:
- I added separate test for showing title and footer together. Not sure if it is needed, but opted on the more test coverage.
- Couldn't find a test for actual usage of `FloatTitle`, so didn't add one for `FloatBorder`.

Here is how it looks:

![neovim_float-win-footer](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/24854248/527abb5e-46ae-4624-97c9-123490c3b2c0)

<details><summary>Code to reproduce screenshot</summary>

```lua
local buf_id = vim.api.nvim_create_buf(false, true)
vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines(buf_id, 0, -1, false, { 'Very important text' })

vim.api.nvim_set_hl(0, 'FloatFooter', { link = 'DiagnosticFloatingHint' })

local row = 1

local open_win = function(config)
  local ref_config = {
    relative = 'editor',
    anchor = 'NE',
    row = row,
    col = vim.o.columns,
    width = 40,
    height = 1,
    style = 'minimal',
    border = 'single',
    title = 'Old boring title',
    title_pos = 'center',
    footer = 'New shiny footer',
    footer_pos = 'center',
  }

  vim.api.nvim_open_win(buf_id, false, vim.tbl_extend('force', ref_config, config or {}))
  row = row + 4
end

open_win()
open_win({ footer = { { 'New shiny footer' } } })
open_win({
  footer = {
    { 'New ',   'DiagnosticFloatingInfo' },
    { 'shiny ', 'DiagnosticFloatingWarn' },
    { 'footer', 'DiagnosticFloatingError' },
  },
})
open_win({ footer_pos = 'left' })
open_win({ footer_pos = 'right' })
```

</details>

comment_data.body:
These two `if` statements cover all variants of `BorderTextType`, but if a new variant is ever added and used you will end up with a read of an uninitialized variable (`field_name` and `field_pos_name`).

Suggestion: either (1) use a `switch` statement (so the compiler will warn you if a new unhandled variant is ever added), or (2) initialize `field_name` and `field_pos_name` to `NULL`, and below this `if` statement add `assert(field_name != NULL)`.

Similar to my other comment, if a new `BorderTextType` variant is ever added you could end up with an uninitialized read from this `if` branch. Same advice as before: either convert to `switch` or initialize pointers to `NULL` and `assert` after the if statement.
maybe `win_get_bordertext_col` as "bordertext" seems to be used regularly for either header/footer.
Symmetry with title is correct here:)
I opted for not using `bordertext` as it doesn't depend on `bordertext_type`.
But it still is only used for these two things. I don't think there is anything more it could be used for as we now have filled both the top and bottom border parts with (potential) text, right?

> But it still is only used for these two things. I don't think there is anything more it could be used for as we now have filled both the top and bottom border parts with (potential) text, right?

I had a crazy idea of maybe allowing text on left and right parts, but can't see useful use case.

note: as #24824 was merged, some adjustments are needed here. They should be quite regular tho. In these added tests `grid 5` should be changed into `grid 4`, the array index `[5]` into `[4]` and finally `id = 1002` into `id = 1001` .
Thanks for the heads up. Done.
